repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Contractual Savings Development
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The achievement of program objectives
            was judged satisfactory. Project sustainability is assessed
            as likely for the reforms as a whole. Overall World Bank
            performance was satisfactory despite the modest results with
            the medium-term components of the program. The overall
            performance of the Borrower was modest. This program was
            highly distinctive in that it was a quick, disbursing,
            single-tranche operation, and one of the first of its kind
            in the region in terms of content. At the same time it was
            negotiated with a government team that changed in
            mid-program. Several lessons can be drawn: The Bank should
            re-examine the instruments it uses for loan programs where
            reforms are politically sensitive and will require a long
            period of gestation. The Bank should in the future wait for
            essential legislative measures to be adopted before taking
            the project to the Board. The Bank must be able to adapt to
            shifts of content and if necessary, revise its expectations
            regarding the degree of Borrower commitment when the
            officials with whom it has to deal change during the course
            of the loan. The Bank should also be more realistic about
            the length of time needed for such a far-reaching reform
            program. Reform of a pension system has to be based on
            actuarial studies and these require access to solid data; in
            this case, these conditions were not fulfilled and the Bank
            needed to allow for the time and cost required to
            reconstitute such data.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Contractual Savings Development
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Contractual Savings Development Loan
            (CSDL) Project is the first in a series of projects being
            developed by the World Bank and Morocco to improve the
            accumulation and allocation of long-term savings and to
            guarantee the long-term sustainability of the country's
            pension system. The project's main objective is to
            improve the allocation of savings to private productive
            investment by reforming contractual savings institutions,
            including insurance companies, savings banks, and the
            pension system. There are four components. The first 1)
            assists in drafting an insurance code, particularly
            concerning foreign ownership provisions; develops an
            insurance sector restructuring plan, and produces a
            timetable to liquidate damage claims; and agrees on a plan
            and schedule to fully liberalize insurance tariffs. The
            second component launches actuarial studies and external
            audits of the existing pension system; appoints a pension
            reform committee; and authorizes independent management of
            pension fund reserves. The third component introduces
            segregated portfolios for the deposits associated with the
            national social security fund (CNSS) and the national
            savings fund (CEN); and replaces the fixed administered rate
            on deposits with portfolio returns from investments. The
            fourth component drafts legislation on portfolio management,
            secured lending, and money market mutual funds.
